isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CATERPILLAR - 1992 - 1993 - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - ENGINE BRAKE CONTROLS

svcprocinfo.para: This manual only discusses engine brake control circuits and components installed by International, including: the Engine Brake ON/OFF switch (188), the Engine Brake Selector switch (187) and the Engine Brake Enable Relay (239). The International installed Clutch Switch and Service Brake Switch also provide inputs to the Engine Brake Control System and are discussed in paragraphs Clutch Switch and Service Brake Switch.
For a complete description of Engine Brake Operation, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Service Manual.
There are two owner selected Engine Brake operation modes, which are COAST and LATCH.

svcsubproc.title: COAST Operation Mode (Standard Mode)
svcsubproc.para: If the COAST mode is selected, the engine brake operates when:

item.para: The driver's foot is off both the throttle and clutch pedal.
The Service Brake pedal is depressed (engine brake only operates while service brake is applied).
The cruise control switch can be in the ON position, although it will be disabled by applying the service brake.

svcsubproc.title: LATCH Operation Mode
svcsubproc.para: If the LATCH mode is selected, the engine brake operates when:

item.para: The driver's foot is OFF both the throttle and clutch pedals.
The cruise control switch must be OFF.

The engine brake operates when the driver applies the service brake, but the engine brake continues to operate (LATCHES ON so to speak) after the driver takes his foot off the brake. The engine brake stays engaged (LATCHED ON) until one of the other ECM inputs changes: clutch pedal depressed, throttle pedal depressed, engine speed drops below 950 rpm or the brake pedal is depressed a second time.

svcsubproc.title: ECM/Driver Engine Brake Control
svcsubproc.para: With PEEC III and 3176 engines, control of the engine brake is shared by the driver and the ECM. The driver turns the engine brake ON or OFF and selects how much engine brake is desired (number of cylinders). The ECM monitors certain engine parameters, then enables the engine brake system when all conditions are acceptable.
The ECM enables the Engine Brake System by energizing the Engine Brake Enable Relay (239) after verifying that the following conditions are present:

item.para: Clutch switch must be closed (pedal released).
Electronic throttle pedal is in the IDLE position (pedal not depressed).
Cruise control must be OFF (see COAST option in paragraph Coast Operation Mode (Standard Mode)).
Engine speed must be greater than 950 rpm.

svcsubproc.para: With Antilock Brakes (ABS) installed, the ignition power from the Engine Brake Enable Relay (239) to the ON/OFF switch is controlled by the ABS system Engine Brake Relay (286). This allows the ABS system to TURN OFF the engine brake when the ABS system detects that a vehicle wheel is encountering a slippery road surface.

To summarize the engine brake controls, the ECM sends a 12 volt signal (when conditions are correct) to energize the engine brake relay (239), and the driver must turn the engine brake ON to ground the engine brake relay and to deliver ignition voltage from the relay to the engine brake solenoids. The ABS system has the ability to turn the engine brake OFF if wheel lockup is about to occur.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Brake Enable Relay (239) AND ON/OFF Switch (188)
svcsubproc.para: To ENABLE (turn on) the Engine Brake Control System, the Engine Brake Enable Relay (239) must be energized. To energize the relay two things must occur:

item.para: The ECM must supply battery voltage through OEM connector (191), terminal 22, to energize the Engine Brake Enable Relay control coil.
The Engine Brake ON/OFF Switch (188) must be in the ON position to complete the Engine Brake Enable Relay (239) control coil ground path.

svcsubproc.para: Turning the Engine Brake ON/OFF Switch to the ON position completes the ground path (24Y/24-G) for the Engine Brake Enable Relay (239) to the cylinder head ground. When all conditions are correct (paragraphs Latch Operation Mode and ECM/Driver Engine Brake Control), the ECM applies 12 volts on circuit 24Z to the Engine Brake Enable Relay (239) energizing coil (terminal 85) causing the relay to energize.

Energizing the Engine Brake Enable Relay causes the relay switch to toggle, closing the circuit between the normally open relay contacts (30 and 87). The Engine Brake Relay common terminal (30) has ignition voltage from 20A fuse F4 present whenever the key is ON. With the relay energized, the ignition power is delivered (circuits 24B/24L) through the closed contacts of the Engine Brake ON/OFF Switch to the Engine Brake Selector Switch on circuit 24C.

With ABS brakes note that the power from the Engine Brake Enable Relay (circuit 24B) must pass through the Normally closed contacts (30 - 87A) of the ABS Engine Brake Relay (286), then circuit 24L delivers the power to the Engine Brake ON/OFF Switch. If the ABS system senses a possible wheel lockup condition, ABS Engine Brake Relay (286) will energize, turning OFF the Engine Brake System.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Brake Selector Switch (187)
svcsubproc.para: The Engine Brake Selector Switch receives power from the Engine Brake ON/OFF switch on circuit 24C.
With the PEEC III 3406C engine, the selector switch directs ignition power through the cab and engine harness to either the front (circuit 24D), rear (circuit 24E) or both engine brake solenoids.

With the 3176 Engine, the selector switch directs ignition power through the cab and engine harness to all three engine solenoids (full brake), or center solenoid only (circuit 24F), or only to the front and rear solenoids (circuit 24D and 24H).
International installs the harness to the solenoids, and the engine brake solenoids are installed by Caterpillar.

important.para: Note the Diode Assembly (two diodes) at connector (240) in the JACOBS BRAKE Circuit diagram. The diodes prevent voltage spikes (spikes are created when the engine brake solenoid field collapses) from entering the electrical system causing damage to electronic components.
